title-group.article-title: Synthesis and properties of novel copolymers of poly(ether ketone ketone) and poly(ether ether ketone ketone) containing amide and sulfone linkages

contrib-group.aff: Department of Chemistry, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang, China

author-notes.corresp: Mingzhong Cai, Department of Chemistry, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang 330022, China. Email: caimzhong@163.com

abstract.p: N, N′-Bis(4-phenoxybenzoyl)-4,4′-diaminodiphenyl sulfone (BPBDAS) was prepared by the condensation of 4,4′-diaminodiphenyl sulfone with 4-phenoxybenzoyl chloride in N, N-dimethylacetamide. Novel copolymers of poly(ether ketone ketone) (PEKK) and poly(ether ether ketone ketone) containing amide and sulfone linkages (PEASAEKK) were synthesized by electrophilic Friedel–Crafts copolycondensation of terephthaloyl chloride with a mixture of diphenyl ether (DPE) and BPBDAS over a wide range of DPE/BPBDAS molar ratios, in the presence of anhydrous AlCl3 and N-methylpyrrolidone in 1,2-dichloroethane. The influences of the reaction conditions on the preparation of copolymers were examined. The copolymers obtained were characterized by different physicochemical techniques. The copolymers containing 10–25 mol% BPBDAS are semicrystalline and had remarkably increased T gs compared to the commercially available poly(ether ether ketone) and PEKK due to the incorporation of amide and sulfone linkages in the main chains. The copolymer V with 25 mol% BPBDAS had not only high T g of 187°C but also moderate T m of 343°C, with good potential for melt processing. The copolymer V had a tensile strength of 102.7 MPa, Young’s modulus of 2.19 GPa, and elongation at break of 14.1%, and it also exhibited high thermal stability and good resistance to organic solvents.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Poly(aryl ether ketone)s (PAEKs) are a family of semicrystalline, insoluble, high-temperature, high-performance engineering thermoplastics. They display an excellent combination of physical, thermal, and mechanical properties and solvent resistance characteristics. This class of advanced material is currently receiving considerable attention for potential applications in aerospace, automobile, electronics, and other high-technology fields. 1 –3 PAEKs can be prepared by one of the two routes, the nucleophilic or the electrophilic polycondensation. 4
–7 The first approach involves the synthesis of nucleophilic aromatic substitution, in which a diaryl ether linkage is formed. 8
–12 The second one involves the synthesis of Friedel–Crafts electrophilic substitution, in which a diaryl ketone linkage is obtained. 13
–18 Although each method has its own merits and drawbacks, the electrophilic route has usually been used to prepare various kinds of PAEKs since the polymerization reaction conditions are mild and the monomers, which are used in the electrophilic approach, have been more selective, cheaper, and readily available. Drawbacks of PAEKs include their high cost, high processing temperatures, and relatively low glass transition temperatures.

For many applications, polymers with different structures and properties are desired. In advanced composite applications, it is desirable to utilize PAEK materials with higher glass transition temperatures. On the other hand, the synthesis and investigation of novel PAEKs would be very useful for a more rigorous structure–property correlation of this very interesting class of polymers. Various structural changes have been introduced in the basic poly(ether ether ketone) (PEEK) resin to obtain different properties and for different applications. The incorporation of a variety of stiff and bulky groups such as diphenyl or naphthalene in the main chains is of considerable interest because it offers good advantages concerning the stability and thermal resistance of the resulting polymer. Considering the fact that PAEKs (e.g. PEEK) suffer from poor creep behavior due to their relatively low glass transitions, the synthesis of novel semicrystalline PAEKs with increased T g is of high interest. Some articles have been published concerning the synthesis of PAEKs containing diphenyl or naphthalene moieties by the nucleophilic aromatic substitution polycondensation in order to improve the glass transition temperatures. 19
–24 Zolotukhin et al. described the synthesis of PAEKs containing naphthalene moiety by precipitation of electrophilic Friedel–Crafts polycondensation, the polymers obtained possess high T g values (>180°C) and also very high T m values (>380°C), which made it difficult to process. 14 Shibata et al. reported the synthesis of the block copolymers of the PEEK and the poly(aryl ether sulfone) containing biphenylene moiety (PEBS). 25 It was found that the degree of crystallinity of the PEEK/PEBS block copolymers decreased with the increase in PEBS content, the glass transition temperature (T g) rose greatly, thereby obtaining superior heat resistance and good mechanical properties.

The whole para-linked poly(ether ketone ketone) (p-PEKK) has made it difficult to process due to its high melting point of 384°C and very poor flowing property. The incorporation of lower content of 1,3-connected meta-phenylene linkages into the backbone of p-PEKK has been shown to produce a substantial reduction in equilibrium melting temperature and a modest decrease in glass transition temperature, 15 this latter effect is attributed to an increase in the overall chain flexibility with the introduction of the meta-phenylene linkages. It is well known that the incorporation of pendant groups also leads to an increase in T g; however, in this case it resulted in the formation of low crystalline or amorphous polymers. To expand the application of PEKK, its melting and thermal properties need to be improved by reducing the melting temperature and enhancing the glass transition temperature. In our previous works, we reported the synthesis of PAEKs which contained diphenyl moieties and soluble aromatic poly(ether amide amide ether ketone ketone)s by electrophilic polycondensation, and the resulting polymers had good potential for melt processing. 26 –28 However, to the best of our knowledge, the synthesis of PEKK and poly(ether ether ketone ketone) copolymers containing amide and sulfone linkages by electrophilic polycondensation has not been reported in the open literature. Recently, we synthesized a new monomer, BPBDAS, via simple synthetic procedures from readily available materials. Considering the fact that the BPBDAS contains both amide and sulfone linkages, we expected that the semicrystalline copolymers with high T gs and moderate T ms could be obtained by the incorporation of lower content of BPBDAS into all-para backbone of p-PEKK. In this article, we synthesized novel copolymers of PEKK and poly(ether ether ketone ketone) containing amide and sulfone linkages (poly(ether amide sulfone amide ether ketone ketone), PEASAEKK) by electrophilic Friedel–Crafts copolycondensation of terephthaloyl chloride (TPC) with a mixture of diphenyl ether (DPE) and BPBDAS, over a wide range of DPE/BPBDAS molar ratios, in the presence of anhydrous aluminum chloride and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) in 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE). The copolymers were characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), wide-angle X-ray diffraction (WAXD), differential scanning calorimeter (DSC), and thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA).

sec.title: Reagents and solvents
sec.p: All reagents and solvents were of analytical grade and were used without further purification unless stated otherwise. TPC (Shuanglin Chemical Co., Nanchang, China) was purified by distillation under vacuum prior to use. DCE (Shanghai Chemical Reagent, Shanghai, China), NMP (Shanghai Chemical Reagent, Shanghai, China), DMAc (Shanghai Chemical Reagent, Shanghai, China), DPE (Shanghai Chemical Reagent, Shanghai, China), and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (Shanghai Chemical Reagent, Shanghai, China) were purified by distillation and dried by 0.4 nm molecular sieve. Aluminum chloride (Shanghai Chemical Reagent, Shanghai, China) was sublimed prior to use. 4,4′-Diaminodiphenyl sulfone (Shanghai Chemical Reagent, Shanghai, China) and p-phenoxybenzoic acid (Shanghai Chemical Reagent, Shanghai, China) were used as received.

sec.title: Synthesis of monomer
sec.p: BPBDAS was easily synthesized by the condensation reaction of 4,4′-diaminodiphenyl sulfone with 4-phenoxybenzoyl chloride in DMAc as shown in Figure 1. Detailed procedures for the synthesis of BPBDAS are described in the following section.

sec.title: Synthesis of polymers
sec.p: The PEKK/PEASAEKK copolymers were prepared as shown in Figure 2 by electrophilic Friedel–Crafts copolycondensation of TPC with a mixture of DPE and BPBDAS, in the presence of anhydrous aluminum chloride and NMP in DCE. A typical reaction procedure for polymer VIII will be described in the following section. Other polymers were also obtained in a similar manner.

To a 150 ml three-necked, round-bottomed flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer, a thermometer, nitrogen inlet, and outlet tubes, 6.541 g (49 mmol) anhydrous AlCl3 and 15 ml DCE were added. The flask was cooled to 0°C using an ice water bath, then a solution of 2.066 g (21 mmol) NMP in DCE (10 ml) was added dropwise by stirring over a period of 10 min and the mixture was stirred for 30 min and then cooled to −15°C. Into the resulting suspension 1.602 g (2.5 mmol) BPBDAS, 0.425 g (2.5 mmol) DPE, and 1.015 g (5 mmol) TPC were added by stirring and the reaction mixture was warmed to 20°C over 2 h and the mixture was maintained at this temperature for 18 h. The reaction mixture was treated with DPE (0.1 ml) as the end capper for 1 h, quenched with methanol (50 ml) at 0°C, the precipitate was crushed, washed with methanol, and extracted with boiling methanol for 24 h and allowed to dry in air. The air-dried product was heated at 100°C overnight under vacuum to obtain the polymer VIII.

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: Elemental analysis was performed with Perkin-Elmer Model 2400 CHN analyzer. The FTIR spectra of the monomers and polymers in KBr pellets (2%) were recorded using a Nicolet FTIR (510P) spectrophotometer. 1 H-NMR (400 MHz) and 13 C-NMR (100 MHz) spectra were obtained with a Bruker PC-A400 (400 MHz) spectrometer at an operating temperature of 25°C using DMSO-d6 as a solvent. Mass spectra were obtained on a Finnigan 4510 mass spectrometer. Inherent viscosities were obtained at a concentration of 0.2 g dl−1 in 95% H2SO4 at 25°C using an Ubbelohde suspended-level viscometer. Weight-average molecular weight (M w) and number-average molecular weight (M n) were determined by an Agilent 1100 gel permeation chromatography (GPC) system in DMF. Polystyrene standards were used as references. DSC measurements were performed on a Mettler Toledo DSC 821e instrument at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 under nitrogen. The glass transition temperature (T g) was read at the mid point of the base line shift and taken from the second heating trace after rapid cooling from approximately 400 to –50 °C. TGA was performed on a Netzch Sta 449c thermal analyzer system at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 in both nitrogen and air atmospheres. The mechanical properties were measured at 25°C using a Shimadzu AG-2000A tester at a crosshead speed of 5 mm min−1. The samples having dimensions of 4.0 × 6.0 × 55 mm3 were cut from the 55 mm2 molding. At least five samples for each polymer were tested, and the average value was reported. WAXD was measured, on powder samples, with a Rigaku D/MAX-IIA X-ray diffractometer, using CuKα radiation at 30 KV and 20 mA. The diffractograms were recorded at room temperature in the range of 10–40°.

sec.title: Synthesis of monomer containing amide and sulfone linkages
sec.p: The route to the synthesis of a new monomer, BPBDAS, is shown in Figure 1. The BPBDAS was conveniently prepared by the condensation of 4,4′-diaminodiphenyl sulfone with 4-phenoxybenzoyl chloride in DMAc at 0–25°C and could also be obtained as a pure material after recrystallization from DMF/EtOH. FTIR, NMR, MS, and elemental analysis were used to confirm the structure of BPBDAS. In the IR spectrum, the key structural features include the following absorptions: N–H stretch, 3386 cm−1, amide C=O stretch, 1665 cm−1, amide C–N stretch, 1400 cm−1, sulfone S=O stretch, 1323 and 1152 cm−1, and Ar–O–Ar stretch, 1243 cm−1. The 1 H-NMR and 13 C-NMR spectra of BPBDAS were in accordance with the proposed structure.

sec.title: Synthesis and characterization of polymers
sec.p: A series of novel copolymers of PEKK and PEASAEKK were synthesized by electrophilic Friedel–Crafts copolycondensation of TPC with a mixture of DPE and BPBDAS, over a wide range of DPE/BPBDAS molar ratios, as shown in Figure 2. It is well known that premature polymer precipitation from the initially homogeneous reaction solution in Friedel–Crafts acylation polycondensation syntheses prevents further macromolecular chain growth reactions and produces polymer with undesirably low molecular weight and poor thermal stability. 16,29 Furthermore, such precipitation Friedel–Crafts polymerization generally produces an intractable product, which is difficult to purify and to remove from the reaction vessel. It is generally accepted that ortho substitution and alkylation of the polymer in electrophilic polymerizations are more likely to occur if the reaction is conducted at elevated temperature for a relatively long time. Janson et al. have reported that the desired melt processable, high molecular weight, substantially linear PAEKs can be obtained by the Friedel–Crafts polymerization reaction in the presence of a controlling agent. 29 The controlling agent can efficiently suppress the undesirable side reactions such as ortho substitution of activated aryloxy groups and alkylation of the polymer, the branching or cross-linking reaction can be controlled. Suppression of side reactions results in a thermally stable polymer that does not degrade or cross-link when subjected to elevated temperatures, for example, at temperatures above the melting point of the polymer for a period of time. Organic Lewis bases such as DMF, DMAc, and NMP are considered to be the preferred controlling agents for the electrophilic polymerization reaction. The 1:1 complex of AlCl3/Lewis base appears to act as a solvent for the polymer/AlCl3 complex formed during the reaction, thereby maintaining the polymer in solution or in a reactive gel state. Furthermore, the reaction mixture is more tractable, making work up of the polymer easier and ensuring effective removal of catalyst residues during purification. The solublization property of the AlCl3/Lewis base complex is particularly significant in the synthesis of para-linked PAEKs.

Initially, in order to determine the optimum polymerization reaction conditions, the influences of catalyst quantity, Lewis base quantity, and monomer concentration on the preparation of the copolymers were examined by Friedel–Crafts acylation of TPC with a mixture of 50 mol% DPE and 50 mol% BPBDAS in DCE using an anhydrous aluminum chloride as a catalyst and NMP as a Lewis base. The preparation of PAEKs by electrophilic Friedel–Crafts acylation polycondensation generally starts at low temperature. The initial low temperature is needed to maintain control over the reaction rate. A reaction temperature of about −15 to −5°C has been found to be particularly effective. Thereafter, the reaction temperature is slowly increased and maintained at room temperature. Concentration of the catalyst is an important factor for the preparation of high-molecular-weight PAEKs. Because the carbonyl groups of the reactants and the reaction products are complexed with AlCl3, thereby deactivating it, AlCl3 is generally employed at more than 1 equivalent of carbonyl groups in the reaction medium. 30,31 The optimum ratio of AlCl3 and carbonyl group was reported to be 1.35:1.45. 13,32 In our modified Friedel–Crafts acylation polycondensation, an additional amount of AlCl3 was required for the formation of a 1:1 complex of AlCl3 and NMP due to the addition of NMP as the controlling agent. Table 1 shows the effect of the AlCl3/TPC feed ratio on the inherent viscosity of the polymer obtained. The polymerization reaction with AlCl3/TPC molar ratio of 8.2 afforded a polymer with a low inherent viscosity of 0.17 dl g−1 due to the absence of a catalytic amount of AlCl3. At least a molar equivalent excess of AlCl3 over the monomer was necessary to obtain polymers with a higher viscosity. The inherent viscosity of the polymer increased with an increase in the concentration of AlCl3. When the molar ratio of AlCl3 and TPC was in the range of 9.2 and 10.2, a polymer with high inherent viscosity (>0.94 dl g−1) could be obtained. However, a large excess of AlCl3, for example, an 11-fold excess, resulted in a decreased inherent viscosity of the polymer. Therefore, a suitable quantity of AlCl3 was about 9.8 molar equivalents relative to TPC.

sec.p: The effect of NMP quantity on polymerization was also investigated and the results are summarized in Table 2. As shown in Table 2, the precipitation polycondensation reaction without NMP afforded a polymer with a lower inherent viscosity of 0.32 dl g−1. The inherent viscosity of the polymer increased with increase in molar ratios of NMP to TPC from 2.0 to 4.2 as a result of maintaining the polymer in solution or in a reactive gel state, but further increasing the quantity of NMP resulted in a decrease in inherent viscosity of the polymer because of the decrease in the rate of polymerization reaction. So, an optimum quantity of NMP was about 4.2 molar equivalents relative to TPC.

caption.p: Effect of NMP quantity on polymerization.a

a Polymerized at 20°C with 2.5 mmol of DPE, 2.5 mmol of BPBDAS, 5 mmol of TPC, and 28 mmol of AlCl3 in 25 ml of DCE for 20 h. In addition, 1 molar equivalent of AlCl3 relative to NMP was required to form a 1:1 complex of AlCl3 and NMP.
b Measured with a concentration of 0.2 g dl−1 in 95% sulfuric acid at 25°C.

sec.p: The Friedel–Crafts acylation polymerization also showed a characteristic effect of monomer concentration on the inherent viscosity of polymers. Table 3 shows the influence of monomer concentration on the polymer viscosity in the course of preparation of the PEKK/PEASAEKK copolymers. As shown in Table 3, the polymer with high viscosity was obtained for monomer concentration in the range of between 0.18 and 0.25 mol l−1. A higher monomer concentration resulted in lower viscosity because the polymerization reaction was too fast and a gelatinous mass was formed after 5 h. However, a too low monomer concentration, for example, a monomer concentration of 0.12 mol l−1, also produced a polymer with lower viscosity due to a low rate of the polymerization reaction.

caption.p: Effect of monomer concentration on polymerization.a

sec.p: A series of novel PEKK/PEASAEKK copolymers were synthesized by varying the molar ratio of DPE to BPBDAS under the optimum polymerization reaction conditions. The polymerization results are summarized in Table 4. The inherent viscosity (η inh) values of the polymers were above 0.68 dl g−1 and increased with an increase in the concentration of BPBDAS in polymer due to the increase in strength of the hydrogen bonding in the polymers. The inherent viscosity (η inh) values revealed that high molecular weight polymers were obtained in DCE/NMP medium since the η inh values of the polymers were higher than the critical η inh value of the macromolecule. In addition, the M n and M w values of soluble polymer X were determined by GPC to be 67,100 and 143,200, respectively, and the polydispersity ratio of M w/M n was 2.1. Thus, the modified electrophilic Friedel–Crafts polycondensation route is appropriate.

b Measured with a concentration of 0.2 g dl−1 in 95% sulfuric acid at 25°C.

sec.p: The key structural features of the polymers obtained could be identified by FTIR spectroscopy. The FTIR spectra of all polymers show no absorption at about 1740 cm−1, indicating the absence of –COCl groups. All the spectra of the polymers except for the polymer I without BPBDAS show characteristic bands at 3433 cm−1 due to N–H stretch, at 1656 cm−1 due to aromatic ketone and amide C=O stretch, at 1400 cm−1 due to amide C–N stretch, at 1307 and 1151 cm−1 due to sulfone S=O stretch, and at 1240 cm−1 due to Ar–O–Ar stretch. The FTIR spectrum of the copolymer V is shown in Figure 3.

caption.p: FTIR spectrum of the copolymer V.

sec.title: Properties of polymers
sec.p: The crystallinities of the polymers were evaluated by WAXD. The WAXD patterns of the polymers I-VII are presented in Figure 4. It is well documented that the polymer I with 100 mol% DPE (p-PEKK) had four major diffraction peaks at 2 θ, which are as follows: 15.8° (020), 18.7° (110), 23.3° (200), and 28.9° (211). 15 As shown in Figure 4, the WAXD patterns of the copolymers II-V with 75–90 mol% DPE fundamentally bore the same number and site of diffraction peak of every crystal plane in comparison with that of the p-PEKK, but the diffraction peaks decreased in intensity with the increase in BPBDAS content due to the incorporation of 4,4′-dibenzoylaminodi-phenyl sulfone moieties in the main chains, which disrupted the regularity of molecular chains and inhibited the close packing of the polymer chains. When the molar ratio of BPBDAS and DPE was up to 30:70, the copolymer VI obtained was amorphous and no obvious diffraction peak was observed. The copolymer VII with 40 mol% BPBDAS was also amorphous and showed only one diffuse diffraction peak. The aforementioned results indicated that the copolymers II-V had a chain similar to that of the polymer I (p-PEKK) to form the crystal in the orthorhombic system with the p-PEKK.

caption.p: WAXD patterns of the polymers I-VII. WAXD: wide-angle X-ray diffraction.

sec.p: The thermal properties of the polymers were evaluated by DSC and TGA, and the results are given in Table 5. Samples were heated up to 400°C at the rate of 10°C min−1 in N2, quenched to −50°C and rerun to obtain T g. The T gs of the polymers II-X were 180–259°C, which exhibited much higher T gs than those of commercially available PEEK 33 and PEKK, 34 whose T gs were 143 and 156°C, respectively. This attributed to the presence of hydrogen bonding and sulfone linkages in the polymers. The polymer I (p-PEKK) with 100 mol% DPE had the lowest T g of 170°C and the polymer X with 100 mol% BPBDAS had the highest T g of 259°C. The increased T g values of the polymers II-X can be explained by the fact that the intermolecular interaction force was enhanced and the segmental motion was hindered due to the presence of intermolecular hydrogen bonding of amide groups and highly polar sulfone linkages. The crystalline temperatures (T cs) of the polymers I-V were 195–258°C and also increased with the increase in concentration of BPBDAS in the polymer. The T ms of the polymers I-V with 75–100 mol% DPE were 343–384°C and the polymer I (p-PEKK) with 100 mol% DPE had the highest T m of 384°C due to the high regularity of molecular chains. The T m values of the polymers I-V decreased gradually with the increase in concentration of BPBDAS in the polymer due to the decrease in regularity of molecular chains with the introduction of 4,4′-dibenzoylaminodiphenyl sulfone moieties in the main chain. When the molar ratio of BPBDAS and DPE was up to 30–70, no melting was observed in the endothermic peak from DSC curve of the resulting polymer VI. The polymers VII-X with 40–100 mol% BPBDAS also showed only a glass transition endothermic peak in their DSC curves. The above results agreed with the WAXD results. The polymer I (p-PEKK) had a higher T g of 170°C, but its too high T m of 384°C made it unsuitable for the melt processing. However, the copolymer V with 25 mol% BPBDAS had not only high T g of 187°C, but also a T m of 343°C, with a good potential for the melt processing. A typical DSC curve of the copolymer V is illustrated in Figure 5.

caption.p: DSC curve of the copolymer V. DSC: differential scanning calorimeter.

fn.p: b Td : the temperature at 5% weight loss.

sec.p: The PEKK/PEASAEKK copolymers exhibited a high thermal stability. As shown in Table 5, the temperatures at 5% weight loss (T ds) of all the polymers were above 475°C in N2 and above 458°C in air. The T d values of the polymers decreased with increase in BPBDAS content in polymer since PAEKs had higher T ds than aromatic poly(ether sulfone amide)s. The polymer I without BPBDAS had the highest T d (in N2) of 559°C, while the polymer X with 100 mol% BPBDAS had the lowest T d (in N2) of 475°C. The semicrystalline copolymers II-V had high T ds of 505–545°C. The temperature difference between T m and T d of the copolymer V was large, thus the melt processing can be easily accomplished. The typical TGA curve (in N2) of the copolymer V is illustrated in Figure 6.

caption.p: TGA curve of the copolymer V (in N2). TGA: thermal gravimetric analysis.

sec.p: The solubility behavior of the polymers prepared in this study was examined for powdery samples at a concentration of 10 mg ml−1 in the solvents at room temperature for 24 h and the results are listed in Table 6. As shown in Table 6, the polymer I (p-PEKK) had an excellent resistance to organic solvents. The copolymers II-VI were insoluble in highly polar solvents such as NMP, DMAc, DMSO, and DMF except for concentrated sulfuric acid, but copolymers V and VI can be swelled in NMP and DMSO. The copolymers VII-IX with 40–70 mol% BPBDAS can be swelled in all of the highly polar solvents and dissolved in NMP. The polymer X with 100 mol% BPBDAS was soluble in highly polar solvents such as NMP, DMAc, DMSO, and DMF. However, the copolymers II-IX were insoluble in common organic solvents such as Tetrahydrofuran (THF), CHCl3, DCE, EtOH, acetone, toluene, and so on. Thus, from the above results, we conclude that semicrystalline copolymers II-V have a good resistance to organic solvents.

a The solubility was tested at a concentration of 10 mg ml−1 in the solvent at room temperature for 24 h.

sec.p: The mechanical properties of the semicrystalline copolymers III-V were measured and the results are presented in Table 7. From these data, it can be seen that the copolymers III-V had tensile strengths of 102.7–105.1 MPa, Young’s moduli of 2.19–2.48 GPa, and elongations at break of 12.5–15.6%, indicating that they are strong materials.

caption.p: Mechanical properties of the copolymers III-V.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A series of novel PEKK/PEASAEKK copolymers were conveniently synthesized by the modified electrophilic Friedel–Crafts copolycondensation of TPC with a mixture of DPE and BPBDAS, over a wide range of DPE/BPBDAS molar ratios, under very mild conditions. The T gs of semicrystalline copolymers II-V were 180–193°C, which exhibited a much higher T gs than those of commercially available PEEK and PEKK, whose T gs were 143 and 156°C, respectively. The T m values of the polymers decreased and then disappeared with increasing BPBDAS content. The T m (384°C) of the p-PEKK homopolymer can be reduced to 343°C when the molar ratio of BPBDAS and DPE is 25–75, moreover the glass transition temperature of the resulting copolymer V can be up to 187°C, 17°C higher than that of p-PEKK. The copolymer V with 25 mol% BPBDAS had not only high T g of 187°C, but also moderate T m of 343°C, with a good potential for melt processing. The copolymer V had tensile strength of 102.7 MPa, Young’s modulus of 2.19 GPa, and elongation at break of 14.1% and exhibited high thermal stability and good resistance to organic solvents.
